summary: The text discusses the prophetic symbolism of the diamond, referencing its indomitable and unbreakable nature as a metaphor for the enduring criticism faced by Christ, particularly from the Jewish people. It illustrates the parallel experiences of the prophet Jeremiah and Christ, both of whom were persecuted by the Jews. It references the historical events of the Babylonian conquest and the Roman destruction of Jerusalem as a fulfillment of biblical prophecy and divine retribution. The text also highlights the eternal curse that the Jewish people invoked upon themselves during the crucifixion, as well as Christ's call for their forgiveness. The narrative conveys a theme of inescapable divine vengeance manifesting through historical events as consequences of past actions.
